name: methyl eicosanoate
Reason: Eicosane as the basic hydrocarbon chain has a melting point of about 37°C. The ester functional group (COO) tends to decrease the melting point due to its polarity decreasing the overall order of the molecular packing compared to a pure alkane, this effect is about -15°C. However, the ester does contribute some dipole-dipole interaction which might mitigate the reduction slightly, making the overall decrease due to the ester group around -10°C. Therefore, the effect of ester group is estimated to be -10°C on the basic hydrocarbon structure.

name: methyl eicosanoate
Reason: The molecule consists primarily of a long hydrocarbon chain derived from eicosane, combined with an ester functional group. Eicosane has a melting point of around 36.8 degrees Celsius. The ester functional group generally decreases the melting point relative to the corresponding hydrocarbon because it disrupts the crystal lattice of the aliphatic chain due to its polar nature as well as potential hindrance in packing efficiency. However, considering the length of the carbon chain in methyl eicosanoate, this effect would be relatively small. Ester group: -5 due to the polar nature affecting crystalline solidity. Long carbon chain: +16.2 (using a reference that each methylene group (CH2) contributes roughly +2.1 degrees Celsius shift compared to methane; with 18 additional methylene groups compared to eicosane). Thus: 36.8 (eicosane) - 5 (ester group) + 16.2 (long chain) = 48 degrees Celsius.
